body:
Looks like this primarily depends on https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/38356

(Or syntex)

Syntex should get this onto stable much more quickly, since the macros > 1.1 effort seems to be just beginning to congeal. 

https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=13245975

> since the macros > 1.1 effort seems to be just beginning to congeal.

This needs more than macros 1.1, it needs 2.0. (If it only needed 1.1, then it could go stable in 1.15)

I intended  `> 1.1`  to indicate "after 1.1"  but that wasn't very clear.   
I've seen the procedural macros effect referenced as 1.2 as well as 2.0.    2.0 does make more sense, since it is a much broader scope, as I understand it.
I've started working on getting `syntex` to work with this until macros are stabilized (which might be a while). I've got time over the holidays from work so I'll post any progress I make!

> I'm all for getting Rocket to work on stable as soon as possible, but I'm not willing to compromise ergonomics and usability to make that happen.

I'd love to see it go stable as soon as possible, but I feel you've got the right values for the project.  Accessibility is arguably more important for web frameworks than it is for other frameworks and libraries.
Just from trying to get it to work with syntex it's hard. I might try some more this week but you're right. It might just be worth it to wait till those features stabilize.

issue.body:
# https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/57563 | new meta tracking issue

# Old content

Tracking issue for rust-lang/rfcs#911.

This issue has been closed in favor of more targeted issues:
- ~Locals, assignments, destructuring: rust-lang/rust#48821~
- Integration with patterns: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/57240
- Floating points: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/57241
- Panics: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/51999
- Loops: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/52000
- Control flow: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/49146
- Comparing raw pointers: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/53020
- Dereferencing raw pointers: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/51911
- Raw pointer to `usize` casts: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/51910
- Union field accesses: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/51909
- Warnings on long running evaluations: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/49980
- Constant propagation not causing errors: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/28238
- `&mut T` references and borrows: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/57349

Things to be done before stabilizing:
- [x] Reach final decision :P
- [x] `const unsafe fn` declaration order https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/29107
- [x] write docs

CTFE = https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compile_time_function_execution

issue.title: move compiler plugins to proc macro

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: A minor feature request

issue.body:
Now that `proc_macto_attribute` has landed, it would be nicer to migrate from old compiler plugin based codegen to the `proc_macro`.

I'm working on an attempt on my fork using pure `proc_macro`, `syn` and `quote`.

It's just a notice in case of duplicated work from someone else.

issue.title: Namespace #[error] behind #[rocket(error)]

labels.name: request
labels.description: Request for new functionality

labels.name: declined
labels.description: A declined request or suggestion

issue.body:
Both `log` and `slog` use `error!` for error logging. This conflicts with `#[error]` as both attribute macros and functional macros share the same scope.

I propose that we make it policy to namespace attribute macros outside of the [standard HTTP methods](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Methods) and `route`.

```rust
#[rocket(error(404))]
fn not_found(req: &Request) -> String { }
```

body: The `lookup_host` feature can be replaced by the `ToSocketAddrs` implementation of `&str`.

Perhaps you could use something like:
https://github.com/Kimundi/rustc-version-rs

In order to allow stable features to compile using stable, but features that require nightly or beta could be used only when compiling from that branch.

Currently using Iron myself and would love to switch but it's a high security project and for security reasons, I want to avoid Rust nightly.

body:
It's been a year since this post originally... seems the check boxes in the original post are accurate?

Seems to me like getting Rocket out of nightly would be a huge boost for Rust in general but especially for Rocket.. the Rocket team or Rust team should really focus on stabilizing these functions (or finding alternatives?).

Why so slow to get there? Have you run this by the Rust higher ups and pushed them a little bit?

issue.title: RFC: Server-side rendering
issue.body: This PR represents my efforts as a beginner Rust programmer to rewrite the UI so that it's rendered by the server, instead of by Ember in the browser. For the pages converted so far, `/` and `/categories`, I refactored the existing JSON API functions so that they could be called by the server to be rendered by the `handlebars` Rust crate. ### Is server-side rendering the right option? I wasn't sure if this would be a welcome change, so I've only gone far enough to have a working prototype. Here's why I think it's worthwhile: + dogfooding + Crates.io could become a great example of how to build server-side apps, like Rubygems.org + this paves the way to write WebAssembly instead of JavaScript + ease of contribution + Ember is a great framework, but for such a simple app it just adds complexity & duplication + the burden on new contributors to learn Rust, Conduit, JavaScript, and Ember shouldn't be understated + performance + the main page takes roughly a second for assets to load & boot, then another second for API requests to finish + the API definitely needs to be optimized, but that first second of delay can only be removed with server-side rendering + security + browser scripting exposes you to risks sometimes as bad as the attacker [gaining local root](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=766253) ### Which web framework? Currently we're using Conduit. There's a lot of options these days; does anyone have experience with those others, and would they be a better choice if we switch to server-side rendering? Similarly, which Crates.io features might be so complex to hand-roll that it makes this conversion much more difficult? OAuth seems likely.

issue.title: Rocket/nightly?
issue.body:
Current Hecate relies on the [Rocket](https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket) web framework, which requires the use of the unstable/nightly Rust compiler. Nightly contains language features that are subject to change, and also [breaks occasionally](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/40106), and at least per the current instructions (which recommend installing the latest nightly), each developer contributing to the project might end up with a different compiler with different features, behavior, and bugs depending on when they happen to set up their dev environment.

Rocket itself [doesn't seem particularly close](https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/issues/19) to running on stable (it seems like a project mostly interesting in pushing the language envelope rather than running on stable), and independent of stable vs unstable, the lead dev anticipates a [major API overhaul](https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket#future-improvements) to move towards async as the Rust async story matures.

The ergonomics do seem nice, but in the interests of building on a solid foundation and making it easy for everyone to work on it, I wonder if we shouldn't consider moving to a framework with a stable API that runs on the stable compiler? [Nickel](http://nickel-org.github.io/) seems like a possibility, or if we wanted to get a head-start on async, maybe [Gotham](https://gotham.rs/) ?

issue.title: Move off of the iron web framework

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

repository.name: indradb
repository.description: A graph database written in rust

issue.body: Move off of the iron web framework, which is not currently maintained. The most obvious candidate is rocket, but the framework currently only works on rust nightly. See progress on their support for rust stable here: https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/issues/19
